abstractContent.text: This article reports on the first machine learning experiments on detection of null subjects in Polish.
It emphasizes the role of zero subject detection as the part of mention detection-the initial step of end-to-end coreference resolution.
Anaphora resolution is not studied in this article.

introductionContent.text: Zero subject detection is an important issue for anaphora and coreference resolution for the nullsubject languages, including all Balto-Slavic languages and most Romance languages.
Their distinctive feature is the possibility for an independent clause to lack an explicit subject.
Person, number, and/or gender agreement with the referent is indicated by the morphology of the verb: (1) Maria wróciła ju˙ z z Francji.
ØHad singular:f eminine spent a month there."
The recently created Polish Coreference Corpus 1 (PCC)) contains zero subject annotation.
A markable representing the null subject is the verbal form following the position where the argument would have been expected.
As tested on the development part of the corpus (described in detail later), omitting a personal pronoun is a frequent issue in the Polish language -about 30% of verbs do not have explicit subjects.

Moreover, these null subjects are often part of large coreference clusters -the average size of a non-singleton coreference cluster in the development subcorpus was 3.56 mentions.
At the same time, the non-singleton coreference cluster containing at least one zero subject had on average 5.89 mentions.
A mention detection module heavily influences the final coreference resolution score of an endto-end coreference resolution system.

In Ogrodniczuk and Kope´cKope´c (2011a) the system working on gold mentions achieved 82.90% F1 BLANC), whereas on system mentions the result dropped to 38.13% (the zero subject detection module was not implemented).
The aim of this paper is to find a method of automatic zero subject detection to improve the accuracy of mention detection as the initial step of coreference resolution.

datasetContent.text: Presented features were used to train a machine learning algorithm.
We chose the JRip implementation of RIPPER (Cohen, 1995) from WEKA () for the possibility to interpret the rules, which is outside of the scope of this paper.
The evaluation corpus was used only for two experiments presented below: to calculate accuracy and learning curve of the developed solution.
We used the model learnt on the development corpus and tested it on the evaluation corpus, achieving 83.38% accuracy.
A majority classifier would achieve 71.76% accuracy on this corpus.
